definition: to burn down/to destroy with fire/trad. also written 焚毀
variant of 毀|毁[hui3]/to destroy by fire/a blaze

sentences.english: Three hours later, stores are looted and the car behind you is on fire.
sentences.chinese: 三小時後就出現了被搶劫的商店和被焚燬的汽車。

sentences.english: Records of Zheng He's incredible voyages were burned.
sentences.chinese: 鄭和令人驚歎的航海紀錄也遭焚燬湮滅。

sentences.english: Perhaps it was because Nero played the fid dle, they burned Rome.
sentences.chinese: 大概是因爲尼祿拉了小提琴，所以他們把羅馬焚燬了。

sentences.english: The mob burnt down the embassy．（burnt the embassy down／burnt it down）
Women mourn and gaze up at the entrance of the damaged building.
sentences.chinese: 兩位女士凝視着被大火焚燬大樓的入口處悼念亡者。

sentences.english: The forest was destroyed by fire.
Namlim Pa was a village with about 400 households before it was entirely burned down to the ground.
sentences.chinese: 在被徹底焚燬之前，南林帕村有大約4百戶人家。

sentences.english: The whole village was burnt down by the puppet troops.
sentences.chinese: 整個村子都被僞軍焚燬了。

sentences.english: The puppet troops burnt the whole village down.
In the fifth year, in the seventh day of the month, at the time that the Chaldeans took Jerusalem, and burnt it with fire.
sentences.chinese: 那時是加色丁人佔領和焚燬耶路撒冷五週年月之七日。

sentences.english: Fire destroyed thousand acres of timber .

definition: to burn down/to destroy with fire
window with an iron grating (apartment etc)/barred window of a prison cell
fire of war everywhere (idiom); enveloped in the flames of war
security measures (esp. border security)/official seal (esp. military seal during Qing and Ming times)
to run away/to flee in disarray
armed enemy of the nation/enemy of the Emperor/fig. championship challenger/contender opposing champion in sporting contest
